title: NeophyteReq

comments.author: OmegaStarScream
comments.body: Are you sure the address you gave us is the same one you've received funds to? You might be using another one.Go to Window -> Receiving addresses -> and check the address that matches the label showing in your screenshot.

comments.author: NeophyteReq
comments.body: In the tab you mentioned, there is only 1 address created in 2018.

comments.author: FatFork
comments.body: Quote from: NeophyteReq on May 26, 2023, 04:18:54 PMbut when I look at the blockchain site, it appears to be empty. Why are bitcoins not showing on the site?Â  Based on the screenshots you provided, it appears that your Bitcoin Core is not yet fully synced with the network, as it is currently 6 years and 29 weeks behind. This may result in some of your wallet's In and Out transactions not being visible to you yet. Wait for the wallet to fully sync and you'll see then.The address you provided does not match the transactions shown in the wallet. You probably mixed something up.

comments.author: NeophyteReq
comments.body: Is there any money in the photo I sent you? or is it out? Even if the bitcoin core is not updated, shouldn't the money appear on the blockchain?

comments.author: LoyceMobile
comments.body: If the address is empty on a block explorer, it may be an altcoin wallet. Doge or Litecoin for instance.

comments.author: BitMaxz
comments.body: Quote from: NeophyteReq on May 26, 2023, 04:53:27 PMIs there any money in the photo I sent you? or is it out? Even if the bitcoin core is not updated, shouldn't the money appear on the blockchain?Why did you call it a test based on your image?Are you trying or experimenting with something?If you already check it on any blockchain explorer and have no funds then it was already sent to another wallet but I check that address on blockchair it doesn't even have any previous transactions. Maybe Loyce is right it might be altcoin?

comments.author: FatFork
comments.body: Quote from: NeophyteReq on May 26, 2023, 04:53:27 PMIs there any money in the photo I sent you? or is it out? The screenshot photo is irrelevant. It doesn't prove anything. (Photos can be manipulated, transactions in the wallet.dat file can be faked...)Quote from: NeophyteReq on May 26, 2023, 04:53:27 PMEven if the bitcoin core is not updated, shouldn't the money appear on the blockchain?I don't know what you expect me to tell you. If the blockchain explorer (or multiple blockchain explorers, for added assurance) says that there are no funds associated with the address, then it's safe to assume that there is no money at that address.

comments.author: Cricktor
comments.body: Quote from: FatFork on May 26, 2023, 04:44:25 PMBased on the screenshots you provided, it appears that your Bitcoin Core is not yet fully synced with the network, as it is currently 6 years and 29 weeks behind. This may result in some of your wallet's In and Out transactions not being visible to you yet. Wait for the wallet to fully sync and you'll see then.Yes, the OP should wait until his Bitcoin Core is fully synced (you will need at least ~550GB of space for the blockchain data and some associated indexes). You could speed up the sync process by increasing the dbcache (default is 450MB) value in your bitcoin.conf file. The value you can set for dbcache during sync depends on how much RAM your Windows computer has and what else you need to do with that computer during the sync process. Some more details from the OP would be helpful to suggest a reasonable value for dbcache.Quote from: FatFork on May 26, 2023, 04:44:25 PMThe address you provided does not match the transactions shown in the wallet. You probably mixed something up.It could be that the OP doesn't understand how the UTXO mechanics of Bitcoin work. If you request a new receive address from your wallet, you will usually get a new one if the previously requested receive addresses got funds sent. When you sent out coins, a suitable amount of input(s) (UTXO(s) in your wallet) are fully spent, your transaction destination gets the desired amount and the excess of coins in the input(s) minus the transaction fees is sent to a change address of your own wallet.Pleople who don't care to learn how Bitcoin actually works, usually don't know much about it (they re-use receive addresses and have not much clue of change addresses, either). I'm not judging...Quote from: FatFork on May 26, 2023, 06:31:29 PMQuote from: NeophyteReq on May 26, 2023, 04:53:27 PMEven if the bitcoin core is not updated, shouldn't the money appear on the blockchain?I don't know what you expect me to tell you. If the blockchain explorer (or multiple blockchain explorers, for added assurance) says that there are no funds associated with the address, then it's safe to assume that there is no money at that address. The remaining coins, if any, might be in other addresses of the OP's wallet. I don't know why the OP assumes all coins are on just one address. This might be, but it's not a very common outcome when a wallet has been in some use in the past. It depends on the history of receive and send transactions with the wallet. The shown screenshots don't allow much to say until the the blockchain has been synced and the wallet's addresses have been rescanned in parallel.

comments.author: FatFork
comments.body: Quote from: Cricktor on May 26, 2023, 08:31:15 PMThe remaining coins, if any, might be in other addresses of the OP's wallet. I don't know why the OP assumes all coins are on just one address. This might be, but it's not a very common outcome when a wallet has been in some use in the past. It depends on the history of receive and send transactions with the wallet. The shown screenshots don't allow much to say until the the blockchain has been synced and the wallet's addresses have been rescanned in parallel.Another thing: Based on the information provided, it seems that there is a discrepancy in the OP's claim regarding the number of addresses in the Receiving addresses tab and the type of wallet shown in the screenshot. The OP states that he only see one address, which would suggest an imported wallet with only one key pair. However, the screenshot provided indicates that it is actually an HD wallet. This does not make sense.
